explicatoryContent.introduction: Have you ever wondered why a ball falls when you let go of it? Or why a skateboard stops rolling after a while? The answer is forces! Forces are all around us. Every push and every pull is a force. Today we will learn how forces make things move, stop, or change direction.
keyPoints: A force is a push or a pull that can make objects move, stop, or change direction
When forces are balanced, an object stays still or keeps moving the same way
When forces are unbalanced, an object changes its motion
Gravity is a force that pulls all objects towards the centre of the Earth
We can show forces using diagrams with arrows
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples used their knowledge of forces to design boomerangs

The force that pulls things down towards Earth
When forces on an object are equal and the object does not change its motion
When forces on an object are not equal and the object changes its motion
A picture that uses arrows to show forces acting on an object
How much matter is in an object

analogies.analogy: Think of balanced forces like a tug-of-war where both teams pull with the same strength - the rope does not move
analogies.explanation: This helps because it shows that equal forces cancel each other out

explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
A force is any push or pull on an object. When you kick a ball, you use a force. When you sit on a chair, gravity is a force pulling you down, and the chair pushes up on you.

Forces can be balanced or unbalanced. Balanced forces happen when the forces on an object are equal in strength but go in opposite directions. When forces are balanced, an object stays still or keeps moving the same way. A book sitting on a table has balanced forces. Gravity pulls the book down, but the table pushes the book up with the same force.

Unbalanced forces happen when one force is bigger than another. When forces are unbalanced, an object changes its motion. It might start moving, stop moving, speed up, slow down, or change direction. When you push a shopping trolley, you make an unbalanced force that makes it move.

Gravity is a very important force. It is the force that pulls all objects towards the centre of the Earth. This is why things fall when you drop them. Objects with more mass feel a stronger pull from gravity. This is why a bowling ball feels heavier than a tennis ball.

Gravity also works in space. It keeps the Moon going around Earth and keeps Earth going around the Sun. Gravity holds galaxies together and even creates black holes.

We can show forces using force diagrams. These are simple pictures that use arrows to show the forces on an object. Bigger arrows mean bigger forces. The direction of the arrow shows which way the force goes.

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples have understood forces for thousands of years. They designed boomerangs with special shapes called air-foil profiles. These shapes use forces from the air to make boomerangs fly in special ways. Different boomerang designs were used for different jobs, like hunting or playing games.

caseStudy.title: How Boomerangs Fly
caseStudy.scenario: Jarra is learning about boomerangs from his Uncle Ken, a Wiradjuri man who makes traditional tools. Uncle Ken shows Jarra how a returning boomerang is different from a hunting boomerang. He explains that the shape of the boomerang affects how air pushes on it. When Jarra throws a returning boomerang, it spins through the air and comes back to him. Uncle Ken explains that as the boomerang spins, one side moves faster through the air than the other side. This creates an unbalanced force that makes the boomerang curve and come back.
caseStudy.elaborationSource: Elaboration 6: analysing the forces acting on boomerangs and how early Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Peoples designed an air-foil profile that could be varied and had several applications
observations: The boomerang has a special curved shape called an air-foil
Different boomerang shapes create different forces
The spinning motion is important for how the boomerang flies
Traditional knowledge about forces helped design effective tools
questions: Why does the shape of the boomerang matter for how it flies?
What forces act on the boomerang when it is flying?
How did Aboriginal Peoples use their understanding of forces to make better tools?
caseStudy.realWorldConnection: Understanding forces helps us understand how Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples developed amazing technologies. Their knowledge of forces was used to create hunting tools, toys, and communication devices over thousands of years.

strengths: The scenario shows real-world application of forces
It connects to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander knowledge and culture
It demonstrates how different designs serve different purposes
improvements: Students could test different boomerang shapes to see how they fly differently
The investigation could include measuring forces with simple tools

options.text: A type of energy
options.feedback: Energy and forces are different things. Energy is the ability to do work, while a force is a push or pull.

options.text: A push or a pull
options.feedback: Correct! A force is any push or pull acting on an object.

options.text: How fast something moves
options.feedback: How fast something moves is called speed or velocity, not force.

options.text: The weight of an object
options.feedback: Weight is caused by the force of gravity, but weight itself is not the definition of force.

remember.stem: What pulls objects towards the centre of the Earth?

options.text: Magnetism
options.feedback: Magnetism is a different force that only affects magnetic materials. Gravity affects all objects.

options.text: Friction
options.feedback: Friction is a force that slows down moving objects. It does not pull things towards Earth.

options.text: Air pressure
options.feedback: Air pressure pushes on objects from all directions, not just downward towards Earth's centre.

options.text: Gravity
options.feedback: Correct! Gravity is the force that pulls all objects towards Earth's centre.

understand.stem: A book is sitting on a table and not moving. What does this tell us about the forces on the book?

options.text: There are no forces acting on the book
options.feedback: There are always forces acting on objects. Gravity is always pulling the book down.
options.misconception: Believing stationary objects have no forces

options.text: The forces on the book are balanced
options.feedback: Correct! The downward force of gravity is balanced by the upward push from the table, so the book stays still.

options.text: The book is too heavy to move
options.feedback: Objects stay still when forces are balanced, not because of how heavy they are.

options.text: Only gravity is acting on the book
options.feedback: The table also pushes up on the book. Both forces together keep the book still.

understand.stem: Why does a bowling ball feel heavier than a tennis ball?

options.text: The bowling ball has more mass, so gravity pulls it down more strongly
options.feedback: Correct! Objects with more mass experience a greater gravitational force.

options.text: The bowling ball is bigger, so it has more air inside
options.feedback: Size alone does not determine weight. A large balloon is bigger but lighter than a small rock.

options.text: The bowling ball is made of harder material
options.feedback: Hardness does not determine weight. The amount of matter (mass) determines how heavy something feels.

options.text: The tennis ball has less gravity acting on it
options.feedback: Gravity acts the same on all objects at the same location. The difference is in the mass of the objects.
options.misconception: Believing gravity varies by object type

apply.stem: You want to push a shopping trolley to make it move. What type of force do you need to apply?

options.text: A balanced force
options.feedback: Balanced forces would keep the trolley still. To make it move, you need unbalanced forces.

options.text: No force is needed
options.feedback: Objects do not start moving on their own. A force is needed to change an object's motion.

options.text: An unbalanced force
options.feedback: Correct! Unbalanced forces cause objects to change their motion, including starting to move.

options.text: A magnetic force
options.feedback: Magnetic forces only work on magnetic materials. Most shopping trolleys are not moved by magnets.

apply.stem: A car is driving at a steady speed on a straight road. What can you say about the forces on the car?

options.text: The forces are unbalanced because the car is moving
options.feedback: Motion does not mean unbalanced forces. Objects can move at a steady speed when forces are balanced.
options.misconception: Believing motion always requires unbalanced forces

options.text: There are no forces acting on the car
options.feedback: Forces are always acting on a moving car, including the engine's push, friction, and air resistance.
options.misconception: Believing moving objects have no forces

options.text: The forces are balanced because the speed is not changing
options.feedback: Correct! When speed stays the same, forces are balanced. The forward push equals the backward friction and air resistance.

options.text: Only the forward force is acting on the car
options.feedback: Many forces act on a moving car, including friction and air resistance pushing backward.
options.misconception: Forgetting about friction and air resistance

analyse.stem: Look at a force diagram showing a falling ball. There is a big arrow pointing down (gravity) and a small arrow pointing up (air resistance). What will happen to the ball?

options.text: The ball will stay in the same spot
options.feedback: With unbalanced forces, objects cannot stay still. The bigger downward force means the ball will move down.

options.text: The ball will speed up going down
options.feedback: Correct! The downward force is bigger, so there is an unbalanced force causing the ball to accelerate downward.

options.text: The ball will slow down and stop
options.feedback: The ball would only slow down if the upward force was bigger than the downward force.

options.text: The ball will float in the air
options.feedback: Floating would require balanced forces. The bigger downward force means the ball will fall.

evaluate.stem: A student says: 'Heavy objects fall faster than light objects because gravity pulls them harder.' Is this correct?

options.text: Yes, this is always correct
options.feedback: This is a common misconception. In the absence of air resistance, all objects fall at the same rate regardless of mass.

options.text: No, all objects fall at exactly the same rate
options.feedback: In real life with air resistance, objects fall at different rates. However, this is due to air resistance, not gravity alone.

options.text: Partly correct: gravity does pull heavier objects harder, but without air they fall at the same rate
options.feedback: Correct! Gravity is stronger on heavier objects, but they also need more force to speed up. Without air resistance, these effects balance out and all objects fall at the same rate.

options.text: No, light objects fall faster because they are easier to move
options.feedback: This reverses the common misconception but is still incorrect. Mass does not determine falling speed when air resistance is removed.

create.stem: You want to design an investigation to test how the mass of a ball affects how far it rolls when pushed. Which is the best plan?

options.text: Use different balls and push them with different forces down different ramps
options.feedback: This changes too many things at once. We need to keep everything the same except mass to see its effect.

options.text: Use balls of different masses, push with the same force, on the same surface
options.feedback: Correct! By only changing mass and keeping force and surface the same, we can see how mass alone affects rolling distance.

options.text: Use the same ball each time and change how hard you push
options.feedback: This would test how force affects distance, not how mass affects distance.

options.text: Drop balls from different heights to see which rolls furthest
options.feedback: This would test how height affects rolling distance, not how mass affects it.

unistructural.stem: Name ONE force that acts on a ball when you throw it into the air.
unistructural.modelResponse: Gravity acts on the ball, pulling it back down to Earth.
unistructural.rubric: Identifies one relevant force acting on an object in motion

multistructural.stem: List THREE forces that might act on a bike rider cycling down a hill.
multistructural.modelResponse: 1. Gravity pulls the rider and bike downhill. 2. Friction between the tyres and road. 3. Air resistance pushes against the rider.
multistructural.rubric: Identifies multiple relevant forces without necessarily connecting them

relational.stem: Explain HOW balanced and unbalanced forces AFFECT the motion of a car. Use examples to support your explanation.
relational.modelResponse: When a car is parked, the forces on it are balanced. Gravity pulls the car down and the ground pushes up with an equal force, so the car stays still. When the driver presses the accelerator, the engine creates a forward force that is bigger than friction and air resistance. These unbalanced forces make the car speed up. Once the car reaches a steady speed, the forward force from the engine equals the backward forces from friction and air resistance. The forces become balanced again, and the car travels at a constant speed. To stop the car, the driver applies the brakes, creating a backward force bigger than the forward force. These unbalanced forces slow the car down.
relational.rubric: Shows clear connections between balanced/unbalanced forces and the resulting motion, with relevant examples

extendedAbstract.stem: An astronaut drops a hammer and a feather on the Moon, and they fall at the same rate. On Earth, the feather falls much slower than the hammer. Use your understanding of forces to explain this difference and predict what would happen in other situations.
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: On the Moon, there is no air, so there is no air resistance. The only force acting on both objects is gravity. Although gravity pulls the hammer harder because it has more mass, the hammer also needs more force to accelerate. These effects balance out, so both objects fall at the same rate. On Earth, air resistance is significant. The feather has a large surface area compared to its weight, so air resistance affects it much more than the hammer. The unbalanced forces are different for each object, causing them to fall at different rates. If we repeated this experiment in a vacuum chamber on Earth, both objects would fall at the same rate because there would be no air resistance. In water, both objects would fall even more slowly because water creates more resistance than air. The hammer would still fall faster than the feather in water because water resistance also depends on shape and surface area relative to mass.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Extends understanding to new contexts by applying the relationship between gravity, mass, and resistance forces to predict outcomes in different environments

explicatoryContent.introduction: Think about kicking a football, riding a bike, or dropping a ball. What makes these actions possible? The answer is forces. A force is any push or pull that acts on an object. Forces are everywhere in our daily lives, from the gentle breeze that moves leaves to the powerful thrust that launches rockets into space. In this topic, we will explore how forces work and how they change the motion of objects.
keyPoints: Forces are pushes or pulls that can change an object's motion, including its speed and direction
Balanced forces occur when forces are equal in size but opposite in direction, resulting in no change in motion
Unbalanced forces cause objects to accelerate, decelerate, or change direction
Gravitational force pulls all objects towards Earth's centre and is related to the mass of objects
Force diagrams use arrows to represent the magnitude (size) and direction of forces
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples applied understanding of forces to design boomerangs with different air-foil profiles

vocabulary.definition: A push or pull that can change an object's motion
The attractive force that pulls objects towards each other, including the force that pulls objects towards Earth's centre
Forces that are equal in size but opposite in direction, causing no change in an object's motion
Forces that are not equal, causing a change in an object's motion
A diagram using arrows to show the size and direction of forces acting on an object
The amount of matter in an object, measured in kilograms
The size or strength of something, such as a force
A device used to measure the size of a force, usually in newtons

analogies.analogy: Balanced forces are like two equally matched teams in a tug-of-war. Both teams pull with equal force, so the rope does not move
analogies.explanation: This helps because it shows that when forces are equal and opposite, there is no net movement

analogies.analogy: Gravity is like an invisible rope connecting every object in the universe. The heavier the objects and the closer they are, the stronger the 'rope' pulls them together
analogies.explanation: This helps because it shows that gravity acts between all objects and depends on mass and distance

explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
A force is any push or pull that acts on an object. Forces can cause objects to start moving, stop moving, speed up, slow down, or change direction. We measure forces in units called newtons (N), named after the scientist Isaac Newton.

When multiple forces act on an object, we need to consider whether they are balanced or unbalanced. Balanced forces are equal in size but act in opposite directions. When forces are balanced, there is no overall force on the object, so its motion does not change. A book resting on a table is a good example. Gravity pulls the book down, but the table pushes up with an equal force. These balanced forces mean the book stays still.

Unbalanced forces occur when one force is larger than another, or when forces do not act in exactly opposite directions. Unbalanced forces cause changes in motion. When you kick a ball, your foot applies a force that is not balanced by any other force, so the ball accelerates and moves.

Gravitational force is one of the most important forces in nature. It is an attractive force that pulls all objects towards each other. On Earth, gravity pulls everything towards the centre of the planet. The strength of the gravitational force on an object depends on its mass. Objects with more mass experience a stronger gravitational pull. This is why heavier objects weigh more than lighter ones.

We can measure forces using a force meter (also called a spring scale or newton meter). A force meter contains a spring that stretches when a force is applied. The amount of stretch tells us the size of the force in newtons.

Force diagrams are useful tools for showing the forces acting on an object. We draw arrows to represent each force, with the length of the arrow showing the magnitude (size) of the force and the direction of the arrow showing which way the force acts. Force diagrams help us understand whether forces are balanced or unbalanced.

Gravity also affects objects in space. It keeps the Moon orbiting around Earth and Earth orbiting around the Sun. The gravitational pull of massive stars holds galaxies together, and extremely strong gravity creates black holes from which not even light can escape.

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples have understood and applied forces for thousands of years. The boomerang is an excellent example of this knowledge. By creating different air-foil profiles (curved shapes that interact with moving air), they designed boomerangs for various purposes. Returning boomerangs use aerodynamic forces to curve through the air and come back to the thrower. Non-returning boomerangs were designed as hunting weapons that flew straight and far.

caseStudy.title: The Science Behind Boomerangs
caseStudy.scenario: Dr. Sarah Wong, an aerospace engineer at the University of Melbourne, studies the physics of boomerangs in collaboration with Wiradjuri knowledge keeper Uncle Eric Bell. Together, they investigate how different boomerang shapes affect flight patterns. Using force sensors and high-speed cameras, they measure the forces acting on boomerangs during flight. They find that the curved shape of the boomerang (the air-foil profile) creates lift, similar to an aeroplane wing. When the boomerang spins, one side moves faster through the air than the other, creating an unbalanced force that makes it curve. Uncle Eric explains how his ancestors developed these designs through careful observation over thousands of years, creating different shapes for hunting kangaroos, scaring birds, or playing games.
caseStudy.elaborationSource: Elaboration 6: analysing the forces acting on boomerangs and how early Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Peoples designed an air-foil profile that could be varied and had several applications
observations: Boomerangs use air-foil profiles to generate lift from moving air
The spinning motion creates unbalanced forces that curve the flight path
Different designs produce different flight patterns for various purposes
Aboriginal knowledge of forces was developed through thousands of years of observation
questions: What forces act on a boomerang during flight?
How does the shape of a boomerang affect the forces acting on it?
Why might different boomerang designs be needed for different purposes?
caseStudy.realWorldConnection: The principles used in boomerang design are applied in modern engineering. Aircraft wings, helicopter blades, and wind turbines all use air-foil shapes to create useful forces from moving air. Understanding these forces helps engineers design more efficient aircraft and renewable energy systems.

strengths: Combines traditional knowledge with modern scientific investigation
Shows practical application of force concepts
Demonstrates how different designs achieve different purposes
improvements: Could include force diagram analysis of boomerang flight
Could compare quantitative force measurements for different designs

remember.stem: What unit is used to measure force?

options.text: Kilograms
options.feedback: Kilograms measure mass, not force. Mass and force are different concepts.
options.misconception: Confusing units of mass and force

options.text: Metres
options.feedback: Metres measure distance or length, not force.
options.misconception: Confusing units of distance and force

options.text: Newtons
options.feedback: Correct! Forces are measured in newtons (N), named after Isaac Newton.

options.text: Joules
options.feedback: Joules measure energy, not force. Force and energy are related but different concepts.
options.misconception: Confusing units of energy and force

remember.stem: What type of force pulls objects towards the centre of the Earth?

options.text: Friction
options.feedback: Friction opposes motion between surfaces. It does not pull objects towards Earth's centre.

options.text: Gravitational force
options.feedback: Correct! Gravitational force is the attractive force that pulls all objects towards Earth's centre.

options.text: Magnetic force
options.feedback: Magnetic force only affects magnetic materials. Gravity affects all objects regardless of their material.

options.text: Electric force
options.feedback: Electric force acts between charged particles. Gravity acts on all objects based on their mass.

understand.stem: A skydiver falls at a constant speed. What does this tell us about the forces acting on the skydiver?

options.text: Only gravity is acting on the skydiver
options.feedback: Air resistance also acts on the skydiver, pushing upward against their fall.

options.text: The forces are unbalanced, causing constant speed
options.feedback: Unbalanced forces cause acceleration (changing speed), not constant speed.

options.text: Gravity and air resistance are balanced
options.feedback: Correct! When falling at constant speed (terminal velocity), the downward force of gravity equals the upward force of air resistance.

options.text: There are no forces acting on the skydiver
options.feedback: Multiple forces act on a falling skydiver. Constant speed occurs when these forces balance.
options.misconception: Believing constant motion means no forces

understand.stem: Two students push a desk from opposite sides with equal force. What happens to the desk?

options.text: The desk moves towards the stronger student
options.feedback: The question states they push with equal force, so neither is stronger.

options.text: The desk does not move because the forces are balanced
options.feedback: Correct! Equal forces in opposite directions balance out, producing no net force and no movement.

options.text: The desk moves in both directions at once
options.feedback: An object cannot move in opposite directions simultaneously. Balanced forces result in no movement.

options.text: The desk breaks because of the pressure
options.feedback: While pressure could damage a desk, the question asks about movement. Balanced forces cause no movement.
options.misconception: Conflating force effects with material stress

apply.stem: A cyclist wants to accelerate faster. According to the relationship between force, mass, and motion, what should they do?

options.text: Add weight to the bike to increase stability
options.feedback: Adding mass would actually decrease acceleration for the same force. More mass requires more force to accelerate.

options.text: Pedal harder to increase the forward force
options.feedback: Correct! Increasing the forward force while keeping mass the same will increase acceleration.

options.text: Coast downhill to save energy
options.feedback: Coasting uses gravity, not increased pedalling force. The question asks about accelerating faster.

options.text: Decrease air pressure in the tyres
options.feedback: Lower tyre pressure actually increases friction and makes cycling harder, not easier.

apply.stem: You are using a force meter to measure the weight of a 2 kg object on Earth. The force meter shows 20 N. If you took the same object to the Moon, where gravity is about 1/6 as strong, what would the force meter show?

options.text: About 3-4 N
options.feedback: Correct! If Earth gravity is 6 times stronger than Moon gravity, the force meter would show about 1/6 of 20 N, which is approximately 3.3 N.

options.text: Still 20 N because the mass is the same
options.feedback: Mass stays the same, but weight (the force due to gravity) changes. The Moon's weaker gravity means less force on the object.

options.text: 0 N because there is no gravity on the Moon
options.feedback: The Moon does have gravity, just weaker than Earth's. It's about 1/6 as strong.
options.misconception: Believing the Moon has no gravity

options.text: 120 N because the Moon is smaller
options.feedback: Weaker gravity produces less force, not more. The Moon being smaller is why its gravity is weaker.

analyse.stem: A force diagram shows three forces acting on a box: 50 N pushing right, 30 N pushing left, and 20 N pushing up. Which statement correctly analyses the motion of the box?

options.text: The box will move up and to the right because there are unbalanced forces in both directions
options.feedback: Correct! The horizontal forces are unbalanced (50-30=20 N to the right) and the vertical force has no opposing force, so the box accelerates both right and upward.

options.text: The box will only move to the right because horizontal forces are larger
options.feedback: Both the horizontal and vertical forces are unbalanced. The box will accelerate in both directions.
options.misconception: Analysing forces in only one dimension

options.text: The box will not move because the total of all forces equals 100 N
options.feedback: Forces in different directions cannot simply be added. We must consider direction when combining forces.

options.text: The box will move left and down
options.feedback: The larger horizontal force is to the right (50 N > 30 N) and the vertical force is upward, so motion would be right and up.

evaluate.stem: A student claims: 'Heavier objects always fall faster than lighter objects.' How would you evaluate this claim?

options.text: Correct - heavier objects experience more gravitational force so they fall faster
options.feedback: While heavier objects experience more gravitational force, they also require more force to accelerate. These effects balance out in the absence of air resistance.

options.text: Incorrect - in a vacuum all objects fall at the same rate regardless of mass
options.feedback: This is true for a vacuum, but the student's claim is not always wrong. In air, differences in air resistance can make objects fall at different rates.

options.text: Partially correct - in air, shape and air resistance matter more than mass alone
options.feedback: Correct! In a vacuum, all objects fall at the same rate. In air, the rate of fall depends on the balance between gravity and air resistance, which is affected by shape and surface area more than mass alone.

options.text: Incorrect - lighter objects actually fall faster because they have less inertia
options.feedback: This reverses the misconception but is equally incorrect. Mass does not determine falling speed in the absence of air resistance.

create.stem: You want to design a fair test to investigate how the mass of a toy car affects how far it travels after rolling down a ramp. Which investigation design would be most appropriate?

options.text: Use cars of different masses, release from the same height on the same ramp, measure the distance travelled
options.feedback: Correct! This design controls the variables that should be kept constant (ramp height and surface) while changing only mass.

options.text: Use the same car, add different masses to it, release from different heights
options.feedback: Changing the release height makes it an unfair test. Height affects speed, which affects distance.

options.text: Use cars of different masses and different shapes on different surfaces
options.feedback: Changing multiple variables makes it impossible to know whether mass caused any observed differences.

options.text: Use the same car each time without changing anything
options.feedback: If nothing changes, you cannot investigate the effect of mass. The investigation requires changing mass while controlling other variables.

unistructural.stem: Name ONE device that can be used to measure the magnitude of a force.
unistructural.modelResponse: A force meter (also called a newton meter or spring scale) can be used to measure the magnitude of a force.
unistructural.rubric: Identifies one appropriate device for measuring force

multistructural.stem: Identify THREE different types of forces that might act on a person swimming in a pool.
multistructural.modelResponse: 1. Gravitational force pulling the swimmer downward. 2. Buoyant force from the water pushing upward. 3. Drag force from the water resisting their forward motion. 4. The thrust force from their arms and legs pushing water backward.
multistructural.rubric: Identifies multiple relevant forces without necessarily explaining how they interact

relational.stem: Explain HOW the relationship between mass and gravitational force affects different objects falling on Earth. Include examples to support your explanation.
relational.modelResponse: Mass and gravitational force have a direct relationship. Objects with greater mass experience a stronger gravitational force pulling them toward Earth's centre. For example, a 10 kg bowling ball experiences about 100 N of gravitational force, while a 0.05 kg tennis ball experiences only about 0.5 N. However, this does not mean heavier objects fall faster. The bowling ball needs more force to accelerate because of its greater mass. In a vacuum, both would fall at exactly the same rate. In air, differences in falling speed are caused by air resistance, not the gravitational force itself. A flat piece of paper falls slowly not because gravity pulls it less, but because air resistance relative to its weight is large.
relational.rubric: Demonstrates clear understanding of the relationship between mass and gravitational force, with examples showing the connection to falling objects

extendedAbstract.stem: A satellite orbits Earth at a constant speed in a circular path. Using your understanding of forces and motion, explain why the satellite requires no fuel to maintain its orbit, yet experiences constant acceleration. Extend your explanation to predict what would happen if Earth's mass suddenly doubled.
extendedAbstract.modelResponse:
The satellite requires no fuel because gravitational force provides all the force needed to maintain its orbit. Although speed is constant, velocity is always changing because the direction changes continuously around the circular path. This change in direction is acceleration, caused by gravity always pulling the satellite toward Earth's centre. The satellite constantly 'falls' toward Earth but also moves forward fast enough that it keeps missing Earth, resulting in a circular orbit.

If Earth's mass suddenly doubled, the gravitational force on the satellite would double. This would create an unbalanced force toward Earth, and the satellite would begin accelerating toward Earth. Its orbit would become elliptical and smaller, bringing it closer to Earth. To maintain the original circular orbit with double the gravitational force, the satellite would need to move faster. This principle explains why objects orbit closer to more massive bodies (like the sun) move faster than those farther away.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Extends understanding of forces and motion to explain orbital mechanics and predicts outcomes in hypothetical scenarios using scientific principles

reflectionQuestions.question: How has your understanding of forces changed after this lesson?
What examples of forces can you observe in your everyday life?
What questions do you still have about how forces affect motion?

selfAssessment.criterion: I can explain how different forces affect the motion of objects
I can distinguish between balanced and unbalanced forces
I can measure forces and represent them in force diagrams
I can describe how gravitational force acts on Earth and in space

studentReflection.connectionToLife: Forces are fundamental to everything around us. Engineers use force calculations to design safe buildings, bridges, and vehicles. Sports scientists analyse forces to help athletes perform better. Understanding forces helps explain phenomena from why boats float to how birds fly. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples' understanding of forces led to remarkable inventions like the boomerang, showing how scientific knowledge develops through careful observation of the natural world.

whatYouWillLearn.coreLearning: This topic explores forces and their effects on motion. You will investigate how balanced and unbalanced forces, including gravitational force, affect objects. You will learn to measure forces using force meters and represent forces using diagrams. You will also examine how an object's mass relates to the forces acting on it and how this affects its motion.
learningIntentions: I am learning to investigate how applying different forces affects objects of varying masses
I am learning to analyse the effects of balanced and unbalanced forces on an object's motion
I am learning to measure forces using a force meter and represent forces using force diagrams
I am learning to investigate Earth's gravitational force and its relationship to mass

successCriteria.criterion: I can investigate and describe the effects of applying different forces to objects of varying masses
successCriteria.evidence: This looks like conducting investigations and explaining results using force-mass-motion relationships

successCriteria.criterion: I can analyse whether forces are balanced or unbalanced and predict the resulting motion
successCriteria.evidence: This looks like examining force diagrams and predicting how objects will move or remain stationary

explicatoryContent.introduction: Every time you kick a ball, ride in a car, or simply stand on the ground, forces are at work. Forces shape everything from the motion of atoms to the orbits of planets. Understanding forces allows us to explain and predict how objects move, why structures stand, and how machines work. In this topic, we will develop a scientific understanding of forces and their effects on motion.
keyPoints: Forces are pushes or pulls measured in newtons (N) that can change an object's state of motion
Balanced forces (equal in magnitude, opposite in direction) produce no net force and no change in motion
Unbalanced forces result in a net force that causes accelerationchanges in an object's velocity
Gravitational force is proportional to mass; objects with greater mass experience greater gravitational force
Force diagrams represent forces as vectors with magnitude (arrow length) and direction
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples developed sophisticated understanding of aerodynamic forces in designing boomerangs

vocabulary.definition: A push or pull acting on an object, measured in newtons (N)
The attractive force between objects with mass; on Earth, this pulls objects toward Earth's centre
Forces equal in magnitude but opposite in direction, producing a net force of zero
Forces that produce a non-zero net force, causing acceleration
The overall force resulting from combining all forces acting on an object
A diagram showing forces as arrows indicating magnitude and direction
An instrument (also called newton meter) used to measure force
The quantity of matter in an object, measured in kilograms (kg)
The rate of change of velocity; caused by unbalanced forces
A curved shape designed to produce lift when moving through air

analogies.analogy: Think of net force like the result of a tug-of-war. If Team A pulls with 500 N and Team B pulls with 500 N, the net force is zero and the rope stays still. If Team A pulls with 600 N and Team B with 400 N, the net force is 200 N toward Team A, and the rope moves
analogies.explanation: This demonstrates how forces in opposite directions combine, and how the net force determines motion

analogies.analogy: Gravitational force is like a universal spring connecting all objects with mass. The spring gets stronger as objects get heavier or closer together
analogies.explanation: This illustrates that gravity acts between all objects and varies with mass and distance

explicatoryContent.conceptExplanation:
Forces are fundamental to physics. A force is any interaction that, when unopposed, changes the motion of an object. Forces are measured in newtons (N), where 1 N is approximately the force needed to hold a 100 g object against gravity on Earth.

When analysing forces, we consider whether they are balanced or unbalanced. Balanced forces occur when the vector sum of all forces acting on an object equals zero. This happens when forces are equal in magnitude but opposite in direction. Balanced forces do not change an object's motiona stationary object remains stationary, and a moving object continues at constant velocity. Consider a book on a table: gravity pulls the book downward with a force equal to the book's weight, while the table exerts an upward normal force of equal magnitude. These balanced forces keep the book stationary.

Unbalanced forces produce a net force greater than zero, causing the object to accelerate. Acceleration is any change in velocity, whether speeding up, slowing down, or changing direction. When you push a trolley, the forward force you apply exceeds friction and air resistance, creating a net forward force that accelerates the trolley.

Gravitational force is a fundamental force of nature. It is an attractive force that acts between all objects with mass. Earth's gravitational force pulls all objects toward its centre. The magnitude of gravitational force on an object depends on its massthis force is what we commonly call weight. Weight (measured in newtons) equals mass (in kilograms) multiplied by gravitational field strength (approximately 9.8 N/kg on Earth's surface).

We can measure forces using a force meter, which contains a spring that extends proportionally to the applied force. The extension is calibrated to display force in newtons.

Force diagrams are essential tools for representing and analysing forces. Each force is shown as an arrow with the tail at the object and the head pointing in the direction of the force. The length of the arrow represents the magnitude of the force. By examining force diagrams, we can determine whether forces are balanced or unbalanced and predict resulting motion.

Gravitational force extends throughout the universe. It keeps the Moon orbiting Earth, planets orbiting the Sun, and stars orbiting the centres of galaxies. At extreme scales, gravity from collapsed stars creates black holesregions where gravitational force is so strong that even light cannot escape.

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples developed sophisticated understanding of aerodynamic forces through the design of boomerangs. By varying the air-foil profilethe curved cross-sectional shapethey created boomerangs for different purposes. Returning boomerangs use differential lift forces created by their spinning motion to follow curved flight paths and return to the thrower. Hunting boomerangs were designed with different profiles to maximise range and impact force.

caseStudy.title: Aerodynamic Forces in Boomerang Design
caseStudy.scenario: Researchers at CSIRO have collaborated with Ngarrindjeri elder Major 'Moogy' Sumner to study the physics of traditional boomerangs. Using wind tunnel testing and computational fluid dynamics, they analysed how different boomerang shapes interact with airflow. The research revealed that Aboriginal craftspeople developed air-foil profiles similar to modern aircraft wings thousands of years before European understanding of aerodynamics. The spinning boomerang creates differential lift forcesthe side moving forward through the air generates more lift than the side moving backward. This unbalanced force causes the boomerang to tilt, and gyroscopic effects then cause it to curve. By adjusting the profile and twist of each arm, traditional makers could control how much the boomerang curved. Uncle Moogy demonstrated how different designs were used for different purposes: sharp-edged designs for hunting, larger curved designs for games and ceremonies, and special designs for communication signals.
caseStudy.elaborationSource: Elaboration 6: analysing the forces acting on boomerangs and how early Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Peoples designed an air-foil profile that could be varied and had several applications
observations: Boomerangs use air-foil profiles to generate aerodynamic lift
The spinning motion creates asymmetric forces causing curved flight
Different air-foil profiles and twist angles produce different flight characteristics
Traditional designs represent sophisticated application of force principles developed over millennia
questions: How do unbalanced forces cause a boomerang to follow a curved path?
What variables in boomerang design affect the forces acting on it during flight?
How does this case study demonstrate scientific knowledge developed by Aboriginal Peoples?
caseStudy.realWorldConnection: Understanding aerodynamic forces is crucial in modern engineering. Aircraft wings, wind turbines, and sports equipment all use air-foil shapes based on the same principles. The boomerang demonstrates how careful observation and experimentation led Aboriginal Peoples to develop aerodynamic technologies thousands of years before modern physics formalised these concepts.

strengths: Demonstrates integration of traditional knowledge with modern scientific analysis
Shows practical application of force principles in technology design
Uses quantitative methods (wind tunnel, CFD) to analyse traditional designs
improvements: Could include student investigation of boomerang flight dynamics
Could provide force measurements for different designs

remember.stem: What is the SI unit used to measure force?

options.text: Newton (N)
options.feedback: Correct! The newton is the SI unit of force, named after Sir Isaac Newton.

options.text: Kilogram (kg)
options.feedback: The kilogram is the SI unit of mass, not force. Weight in newtons equals mass in kilograms multiplied by gravitational field strength.
options.misconception: Confusing units of mass and force

options.text: Joule (J)
options.feedback: The joule is the SI unit of energy. Force is measured in newtons.
options.misconception: Confusing units of energy and force

options.text: Watt (W)
options.feedback: The watt is the SI unit of power. Force is measured in newtons.
options.misconception: Confusing units of power and force

remember.stem: What is the relationship between an object's mass and the gravitational force it experiences?

options.text: Greater mass results in smaller gravitational force
options.feedback: This is the opposite of the actual relationship. Gravitational force increases with mass.

options.text: Mass has no effect on gravitational force
options.feedback: Mass directly affects gravitational force. Objects with greater mass experience greater gravitational force.
options.misconception: Believing mass and gravity are unrelated

options.text: Greater mass results in greater gravitational force
options.feedback: Correct! Gravitational force is directly proportional to mass. Objects with more mass experience stronger gravitational pull.

options.text: Only objects above a certain mass experience gravitational force
options.feedback: All objects with mass experience gravitational force, regardless of how small the mass is.
options.misconception: Believing gravity only affects large objects

understand.stem: A spacecraft travels through deep space at constant velocity. What can be concluded about the forces acting on it?

options.text: A forward force must be acting to maintain the velocity
options.feedback: In the absence of friction or drag, no force is needed to maintain constant velocity. This is Newton's First Law.
options.misconception: Believing constant motion requires constant force

options.text: No net force is acting on the spacecraft
options.feedback: Correct! Constant velocity means no acceleration, which means no net force. The forces acting on the spacecraft are balanced.

options.text: The gravitational force equals the thrust force
options.feedback: In deep space far from planets, gravitational force is negligible. Constant velocity simply means no net force.
options.misconception: Assuming specific force types must be present

options.text: The spacecraft must be accelerating
options.feedback: Constant velocity by definition means no acceleration. Acceleration requires a net force.

understand.stem: When a ball is thrown upward, what happens to the forces acting on it at the highest point of its path?

options.text: All forces become zero momentarily
options.feedback: Gravity acts continuously on the ball throughout its flight, including at the highest point.
options.misconception: Believing zero velocity means zero force

options.text: Gravity reverses direction to stop the ball
options.feedback: Gravity always acts downward toward Earth's centre. It never reverses direction.

options.text: Gravity continues to act downward with the same magnitude
options.feedback: Correct! Gravity acts continuously throughout the ball's flight. At the highest point, the ball has zero velocity but is still accelerating downward due to gravity.

options.text: The upward force from the throw equals gravity
options.feedback: Once the ball leaves your hand, there is no upward force from the throw. The only significant force is gravity.

apply.stem: Two identical shopping trolleys have different amounts of groceries in them. If the same pushing force is applied to both, what will happen?

options.text: Both trolleys will accelerate at the same rate
options.feedback: The relationship between force, mass, and acceleration means that for the same force, more mass results in less acceleration.
options.misconception: Ignoring the effect of mass on acceleration

options.text: The heavier trolley will accelerate faster
options.feedback: This is the opposite of what happens. Greater mass requires greater force to achieve the same acceleration.

options.text: The lighter trolley will accelerate faster
options.feedback: Correct! For the same force, less mass means greater acceleration. The lighter trolley requires less force to achieve the same acceleration.

options.text: Neither trolley will accelerate because the forces are balanced
options.feedback: If a net force is applied (pushing force exceeds friction), the trolleys will accelerate.

apply.stem: A force meter is used to measure the weight of an object on Earth and records 50 N. If the object is taken to a planet with double Earth's gravitational field strength, what reading would the force meter show?

options.feedback: This would be the result if gravity were halved, not doubled.
The same mass experiences different gravitational force depending on the gravitational field strength.
options.misconception: Confusing mass (constant) with weight (varies with gravity)

options.feedback: Correct! Weight is proportional to gravitational field strength. Double the field strength means double the weight.
Double the gravitational field strength would double the weight from 50 N to 100 N, not 200 N.

analyse.stem: A force diagram shows a car with a 6000 N forward force from the engine and a combined 4500 N backward force from friction and air resistance. Gravity (15000 N down) and normal force (15000 N up) are also shown. Which analysis is correct?

options.text: The vertical forces are unbalanced, causing upward acceleration
options.feedback: The vertical forces (15000 N each) are equal and opposite, so they are balanced.

options.text: The horizontal forces are unbalanced with a 1500 N net force forward, causing the car to accelerate
options.feedback: Correct! 6000 N forward minus 4500 N backward gives a net force of 1500 N forward. This causes the car to accelerate forward.

options.text: All forces are balanced, so the car maintains constant velocity
options.feedback: The horizontal forces are not balanced (6000 N  4500 N), so there is a net force causing acceleration.
options.misconception: Not checking all force pairs for balance

options.text: The net force is 1500 N backward, causing deceleration
options.feedback: The forward force (6000 N) is greater than the backward force (4500 N), so the net force is forward.

evaluate.stem: A student argues that 'gravity is not a force because you cannot push or pull with gravity like you can with your hands.' Evaluate this argument.

options.text: The argument is valid because gravity is not directly observable
options.feedback: While we cannot see gravity, its effects are observable and measurable. This does not disqualify it from being a force.

options.text: The argument is invalid because a force does not need direct physical contact to act
options.feedback: Correct! Forces can act at a distance. Gravity, magnetic forces, and electric forces all act without physical contact. This is a defining characteristic of field forces.

options.text: The argument is valid because gravity is actually energy, not a force
options.feedback: Gravity is a force. It can be described by gravitational potential energy, but the gravitational interaction is a force.

options.text: The argument is partially valid because gravity is weaker than contact forces
options.feedback: The strength of a force does not determine whether it is a force. Gravity can be extremely strong (e.g., near black holes).
options.misconception: Confusing force magnitude with force classification

create.stem: You need to design an investigation to determine how the mass of a falling object affects the air resistance force it experiences at terminal velocity. Which approach would yield the most useful data?

options.text: Drop objects of different masses from the same height and measure time to fall
options.feedback: This would show differences in falling time but wouldn't directly measure air resistance force.
options.misconception: Not measuring the target variable directly

options.text: Use a vertical wind tunnel with objects attached to force meters, measuring force at different wind speeds until the force equals the object's weight
options.feedback: Correct! At terminal velocity, air resistance equals weight. Using a wind tunnel with force meters allows direct measurement of the air resistance force for different masses.

options.text: Drop different objects and observe which falls faster
options.feedback: This provides qualitative observations only, not quantitative measurements of force.
options.misconception: Confusing qualitative observation with quantitative measurement

options.text: Calculate air resistance using the formula without experimentation
options.feedback: An investigation requires experimental data collection. Calculations alone do not constitute an investigation.

unistructural.stem: Identify ONE factor that affects the magnitude of gravitational force on an object at Earth's surface.
unistructural.modelResponse: The mass of the object affects the magnitude of gravitational force. Objects with greater mass experience greater gravitational force.
unistructural.rubric: Correctly identifies mass as a factor affecting gravitational force

multistructural.stem: List FOUR different forces that act on a car travelling along a flat road at constant velocity.
multistructural.modelResponse: 1. Gravitational force (weight) pulling the car downward. 2. Normal force from the road pushing the car upward. 3. Driving force from the engine pushing the car forward. 4. Friction/air resistance opposing the car's motion.
multistructural.rubric: Identifies multiple relevant forces acting on the car without necessarily explaining their relationships

relational.stem: Explain HOW the concepts of balanced and unbalanced forces can be used to analyse the motion of a person in an elevator that is accelerating upward.
relational.modelResponse: When a person stands in an accelerating elevator, they experience two main vertical forces: gravitational force (weight) acting downward and normal force from the elevator floor acting upward. During upward acceleration, the normal force must be greater than the gravitational force to create an unbalanced net force upward. This net force causes the upward acceleration. The person feels 'heavier' because the floor pushes harder against them than it would if stationary. If the elevator were moving at constant velocity, the forces would be balancedthe normal force would equal the weightand there would be no acceleration. When the elevator decelerates (slows while going up), the normal force becomes less than the weight, creating a net downward force and the person feels lighter.
relational.rubric: Clearly connects balanced and unbalanced forces to the motion of the elevator, explaining how force relationships change during different phases

extendedAbstract.stem: The International Space Station (ISS) orbits Earth at approximately 400 km altitude, travelling at about 7.66 km/s. Astronauts inside experience 'weightlessness' despite being in Earth's gravitational field. Using your understanding of forces and motion, explain this apparent contradiction and predict how an astronaut's experience would change if the ISS were placed in a higher orbit.
extendedAbstract.modelResponse:
The apparent contradiction is resolved by understanding that both the ISS and the astronauts inside are continuously falling toward Earth due to gravity. They experience 'weightlessness' not because gravity is absent, but because there is no normal forcenothing is pushing against them. The gravitational force provides exactly the centripetal force needed to maintain their circular orbit. Both the station and astronauts accelerate toward Earth at the same rate, so there is no relative force between them.

At 400 km altitude, gravity is about 88% as strong as at Earth's surface. The astronauts are definitely experiencing gravitational forcethey are not truly weightless, they are in free fall.

If the ISS were moved to a higher orbit, several things would change. Gravitational force would be weaker at greater distance. The required orbital velocity would be lower (following Kepler's laws). The orbital period would be longer. However, the astronauts would still experience weightlessness because they would still be in free fall with the station. The sensation would be identicalit depends on the absence of normal force, not on the strength of gravity. Only if the ISS moved to a geostationary orbit (approximately 35,800 km altitude) would the orbital period match Earth's rotation, but astronauts would still experience weightlessness.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Extends understanding beyond the curriculum to explain a complex phenomenon, correctly applying force concepts to orbital mechanics and predicting outcomes in hypothetical scenarios
